misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Array indexing starts at 1 (off-by-one / bounds misunderstanding)
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes arrays in Java are 1-indexed (valid indices are 1..N), so loops should start at 1 and go up to N inclusive, and accessing userNumbersArray[currentIndex] with currentIndex==N is valid.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-indexed: valid indices are 0..length-1. A loop that runs currentIndex = 1; currentIndex <= arraySize; currentIndex++ will (a) skip index 0 entirely and (b) attempt to access index arraySize, which is out of bounds and causes a runtime crash. This affects both filling the array and searching it.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException during input (and would also occur during search if it got that far). Even if it didn’t crash, it would never consider element 0, so the “first occurrence” result would be wrong when T is at index 0.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that arrays in Java are 1-indexed, so when storing or accessing array elements, they should start at index 1 rather than index 0. They also believe that the target index returned should be 1-indexed to match this mental model.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed, meaning the first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and so on. The student has confused array indexing with 1-based counting. Additionally, the problem requires returning the 0-indexed position (as shown in the sample run where element 20 is at index 1, not index 2), but the student's code stores at index 1 instead of index 0, causing both an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException on valid input and incorrect index reporting.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException when reading array elements, and if that were somehow avoided, the index returned would be off by one (returning 2 instead of 1 for the sample input).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that array indices start at 1 and end at the value equal to the array's size, mirroring how one might count objects in real life.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays use zero-based indexing, meaning the first element is at index 0 and the last element is at index length-1. The student's mental model fails to account for the zero-index start and the fact that accessing an index equal to the array length is out of bounds.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes Java arrays are indexed starting at 1 (up to N), so loops should run from 1 to N inclusive and it’s valid to access arr[N].
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are 0-based: valid indices are 0 to N-1. Using 1..N skips index 0 and attempts to access index N, which does not exist. This causes a runtime failure and prevents correct searching/printing.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException (attempting to read/write userNumbersArray[arraySize]).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are 1-indexed (starting from index 1), similar to how arrays work in languages like MATLAB or mathematical notation. They assume an array of size N should be accessed using indices 1 through N.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java arrays are 0-indexed, meaning an array of size N has valid indices from 0 to N-1. Starting loops at index 1 and iterating up to and including index N causes the code to skip index 0 and attempt to access index N, which is out of bounds. This is a fundamental misunderstanding of Java's array indexing model.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException will be thrown at runtime when the loop attempts to access userNumbersArray[arraySize], since the maximum valid index is arraySize-1.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that Java arrays are 1-indexed, starting at 1 and ending at the integer value representing the array size.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: Java utilizes 0-based indexing for arrays. For an array of size N, the valid indices range from 0 to N-1. By starting the loops at 1 and continuing until the index is equal to the array size, the student's mental model skips the actual first element (index 0) and attempts to access an out-of-bounds memory location (index N).
